bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, October 3, 1953

div1.p: Truby describes his physical condition and also states that Finlay deserves credit for all the help he gave to Reed. He encloses a letter from John Kelly.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, October 3, 1953
div1.opener:
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco 18, California
October 3, 1953
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I had intended writing you a long letter to be at your home upon
your return from Europe. Conditions, however, seem to have made
that impossible as I had a virus attack some months ago, and since
that time, my right knee has gradually lost much of the progress
it had made before. So, instead of getting better with exercise,
it got worse. I gradually realized that something was wrong and
so I took the matter up with the Chief of the PT Service and for
the first time, I got action. A new doctor, Capt. Trainor, took
me over and unfolded a lot of new and astounding ideas which I
think will get us back on the right track. Trainor has only been
here a few days and I think has recently been at the Mayo Clinic.
(As soon as possible I will find out about him and advise you.)
He has been so busy with me and other cases here that I have not
had time to find out much about him, but I am most heartily pleased
with the way he has taken hold of things, and for the first time,
I feel I am in proper hands, with a man in charge who knows his
stuff. I received their routine treatment here but evidently it
was not suited to my case. I have no trouble to speak of except
with my right knee in that I cannot flex it when walking. The
condition was properly diagnosed after I was in the hospital a
year and I suppose I have told you some time or other that the real
trouble was that the quadricepts on that side was stronger than the
hamstrings and other muscles which produced flexion. The result is
that when I walk I not only strengthen the hamstrings and other
muscles involved, but at the same time, the quadricepts gets stronger
and stronger, and I failed to make the progress which I did at first.
Really, am losing by the exercise. Now, we are endeavoring to cut
out exercises which strengthen the quadricepts and have adopted
a new method of exercising the other muscles I mentioned by utilizing
the old principle of reflex action. For the hamstrings, for
instance, they twist my right big toe and up comes my leg as if
nothing were the matter with it by involuntary hamstring action. In
that way, we exercise that group of muscles without much effort on
my part. After doing that a few times, I can do it myself. That
is an entirely new thing here, and I am the first one here to be
treated in that way. After nearly two years at the Letterman, I
have great hopes of getting real results, but so far I am not making
any predictions except to let you know that I find Capt. Trainor a
real live wire and he believes that the prospects in my case will
be excellent. Now, I will be able to let you know more about this
in the next month.

First of all, here are a few things which I have been wanting to
write about, but I will only touch on them briefly. I was most
appreciative of your telegram about the cost analysis I made of
the yellow fever cases at old Camp Lazear, also the letter which
repaid me for all efforts I have put out to do a good job. I
also want to thank you and your secretary for mailing the article
by Dr. Tocantins on “Yellow Fever, Mosquitoes, and Carlos Finlay.”
I was quite pleased to see the illustrations, especially the 7-8
foot wall of white limestone rock. I think it is beautiful.
When will you be able to publish your little article about the
dedication, last December? I also wish to tell you that I have
heard from Father Kelly and will enclose a copy of his letter
to me. When I wrote him I explained my physical difficulties and
told him he could probably get a copy of my book from Dr. Nogueira.
There he will find many references which explain my admiration for
the very courteous old doctor who was so kind and helpful to me.
I also told him that Dr. Finlay's deep interest and belief in his
theory was responsible for his clinging so persistently to it
throughout the years. Finlay should really get credit for the
help that he gave Reed and others to prove it.

If Dr. Trainor's ideas come through as he expects, I shall be very
glad to furnish you with short accounts about Reed and the other
members of the Board. But I am in no condition to tackle that just
yet. When I get so that I can keep on my feet without breaking my
neck in the many falls which continue to bother me, I will soon be
able, I think, to summarize all that I know about them.

I am still up in the air about the rent matter. Our landlord has
not yet notified us of the increase but it will be very unreasonable
I am sure.

I will now try to hurry this off and hope it gets to Rochester
before you are ready to go to work on your stack of correspondence.
When I hear from you I will probably know more about Dr. Trainor
but the last few days have encouraged me still more and I am quite
sure that he is already getting results in my case. I was just about
ready to quit when this new development came.

I am sure you and your family had a most enjoyable and restful trip.
Remember, it is time to take it easy. With best wishes to everyone,
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, AET Albert E. Truby
Brigadier General
U. S. A., Retires Retired
